header_summary:
A new release candidate, Bitcoin Core version v26.0rc3, is now available for community testing, downloadable from the official website or via a verified tag on GitHub. This update marks a significant milestone in the development of Bitcoin Core as it prepares for a major release, with preliminary release notes published on GitHub to outline the latest improvements.

Michael Ford's announcement of the candidate's availability prompted Bastien Teinturier to raise concerns about the sufficiency of information provided for a comprehensive summary. Teinturier stressed the need for complete email contents to ensure any derived summary accurately conveys all critical discussions, decisions, and technical specifics.

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Core 26.0 release candidate 3 available
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core version v26.0rc3 is now available for download.
- Release notes with changes and improvements since the last version are on GitHub.
- If no critical issues arise, v26.0rc3 will become the official v26.0 release.

recent_posts.title: Mailing List Future
recent_posts.summary:
- Bastien Teinturier addresses an incomplete email context received.
- He requests the full email to accurately create a summary or blog post.
- Essential details like key points, decisions, and technical specifics are needed.

active_posts.title: Ordinals BIP PR
active_posts.summary:
- The sender has repeatedly sought a response on the Ordinals BIP PR without success.
- BIP acceptance as technical documentation doesn't imply community consensus or implementation.
- They request specific BIP editors' guidance on making the Ordinals BIP acceptable.

active_posts.title: HTLC output aggregation as a mitigation for tx recycling, jamming, and on-chain efficiency (covenants)
active_posts.summary:
- HTLC output aggregation consolidates all active HTLCs into a single transaction output to enhance chain efficiency.
- Aggregated outputs allow more HTLCs without increasing commitment size, addressing slot jamming liabilities.
- Implementation requires new covenant primitives and a recursive covenant for effective HTLC management.

active_posts.title: A proposal for a "PSBT for descriptors" format
active_posts.summary:
- SeedHammer is developing a compact metal backup descriptor using PSBT encoding.
- The format aligns with BIPs 380-386 and BIP 389, excluding inline keys and pk(NAME) expressions.
- Debate exists between using CBOR or PSBT, with SeedHammer favoring PSBT for its simplicity.

active_posts.title: Lightning Address in a Bolt 12 world
active_posts.summary:
- Enhancements to lightning address protocol target user experience, privacy, and security.
- DNS `TXT` records may privately link domains to nodes, protecting sender identity.
- Only two design options are suggested for simplicity; community feedback will inform a bLIP.

active_posts.title: Liquidity Ads: Updated Spec Posted, please review
active_posts.summary:
- Liquidity Ads specification revision transitions funds locking from CSV to CLTV.
- New concept of "lease locked" transactions prevents leasors from early fund access.
- Modifications include variable lease terms and more granular channel fee increments.

active_posts.title: HTLC output aggregation as a mitigation for tx recycling, jamming, and on-chain efficiency (covenants)
active_posts.summary:
- HTLC output aggregation prevents transaction recycling and channels jamming by collapsing outputs.
- A covenant enables spenders to only claim their share, improving transaction security and efficiency.
- New Layer 1 covenant primitives and PTLCs may ultimately resolve slot jamming issues.
